sources.title: Articles on Smashing Magazine ‚Äî For Web Designers And Developers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Arihant Verma)
articles.description: In this article, we‚Äôll discuss and learn about the use case of iterating over React `children` and the ways to do it. In particular, we will deep dive into one of the utility methods, `React.Children.toArray`, that React gives us, which helps to iterate over the children in a way which ensures performance and determinism.
articles.title: React Children And Iteration Methods

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Callum Hart)
articles.description: Resilience is intrinsic to the web and therefore us, web developers. This article explores how graceful degradation, defensive coding, observability, and a healthy attitude towards failures better equips us before, during, and after an error occurs.
articles.title: How To Build Resilient JavaScript UIs

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Adrian Bece)
articles.description: In this article, we‚Äôll take a deep dive into the refactoring process itself, and cover incremental refactoring strategy, visual regression testing, and maintaining the refactored codebase.
articles.title: Refactoring CSS: Strategy, Regression Testing And Maintenance (Part 2)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: New month, new wallpapers! In this post, you‚Äôll find unique and inspiring wallpapers for August 2021. Created with love by the community for the community, they come in versions with and without a calendar for the month.
articles.title: Good Vibes In August (2021 Desktop Wallpapers Edition)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Zara Cooper)
articles.description: Having an e-commerce store is crucial for any store owner as more and more customers are turning to online shopping. In this tutorial, we shall go through how to create an e-commerce site with Angular 11. The site will use the Commerce Layer as a headless e-commerce API and use Paypal to process payments.
articles.title: How To Build An E-Commerce Site With Angular 11, Commerce Layer And Paypal

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Elad Shechter)
articles.description: What are absolute units? What are the differences between relative and absolute units, and how do we create accurate sizes on the web? In this article, Elad Shechter explains why CSS absolute units aren‚Äôt so absolute.
articles.title: There Is No Such Thing As A CSS Absolute Unit

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Kitty Giraudel)
articles.description: Dialogs are everywhere in modern interface design (for good or for bad), and yet many of them are not accessible to assistive technologies. In this article, we will dig into how to create a short script to create accessible dialogs.
articles.title: Creating An Accessible Dialog From Scratch

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Alexander Dubovoy)
articles.description: Next.js has strong opinions about how to organize JavaScript but not CSS. How can we develop patterns that encourage best CSS practices while also following the framework‚Äôs logic? The answer is surprisingly simple ‚Äî to write well-structured CSS that balances global and local styling concerns.
articles.title: Global vs. Local Styling In Next.js

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Paul Scanlon)
articles.description: Gatsby recently announced the launch of ‚Äúfunctions‚Äù. In this article, Paul Scanlon explains how to get the current location of the International Space Station (ISS) as it orbits the Earth in real-time using [Gatsby Functions](https://www.gatsbyjs.com/docs/reference/functions/) and then display it on a 3D interactive globe using [React Three Fibre](https://github.com/pmndrs/react-three-fiber).
articles.title: Gatsby Serverless Functions And The International Space Station

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Paul Boag)
articles.description: Many web design agencies consider it a badge of honor that they win work exclusively through word-of-mouth recommendations. In this article, Paul Boag explains why that is entirely the wrong attitude and what to do about it.
articles.title: A Guide To Attracting Clients To Your Agency

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Matthew Talebi)
articles.description: Are you running a business and have too many things going on at once? Meetings, bugs, customer feedback, new clients in addition to your already tight deadlines? Let‚Äôs face it, time management is hard, and it becomes even more difficult in the trying times we are in.
articles.title: Adding Time To Your Schedule As A Professional

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: Do you need a little inspiration boost? We‚Äôve collected some useful color tools and resources that we‚Äôve discovered lately ‚Äî to help you get the most out of your creativity. We‚Äôve also just recently covered [CSS auditing tools](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2021/03/css-auditing-tools/), [CSS generators](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2021/03/css-generators/), [accessible front-end components](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2021/03/complete-guide-accessible-front-end-components/), [front-end boilerplates](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2021/06/useful-frontend-boilerplates-starter-kits/) and [VS code extensions](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2021/05/useful-vs-code-extensions-web-developers/) ‚Äî you might find them useful, too.
articles.title: Color Tools And Resources

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Alba Silvente)
articles.description: In this article, we will look at when it makes sense to migrate from a monolithic project to a headless setup and the benefits that come with it. In addition to a step-by-step guide on how to migrate WordPress to Storyblok Headless CMS, the problems that will arise during the process and how to deal with them.
articles.title: How To Migrate From WordPress To A Headless CMS

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Colby Fayock)

articles.title: You Can Do That With A JavaScript Data Grid?

<template>
  {{ title }}
</template>

<script>

articles.author: Aya Bouchiha
articles.description:
Hello,
Aya Bouchiha,
firstly, we need to know that handling events can be done with:
onEventName
example:
showButton.onclick = handleClick;

addEventListener('eventName', function)
example:
showButton.addEventListener('click', handleClick)

The event as a attribute (onEventName="function()")




<button onclick="doSomething()"></button>

focus: This happens when the user focuses on the input field.
blur: happens when the user leaves the input field.





  
  
  input


input: This happens immediately when the user changes the input's value.





  
  
  reset


reset: This happens when a form is reset by clicking to a reset input or a reset button.





  
  
  submit


submit: This happens when a form is submitted, by clicking a submit button or a submit input.





  
  
  Summary



focus happens when the user leaves the input field.
blur: happens when the user focuses on the input field.
input: happens immediately when the user changes the input's value.
reset: happens when a form is reset.
submit: This happens when a form is submitted.
www.developer.mozilla.org
www.w3schools.com

articles.author: Rafael Ribeiro
articles.description:
Python Brasil 2021, a maior confer√™ncia de Python da Am√©rica Latina, acontecer√° entre os dias 11 e 17 de outubro, reunindo desenvolvedores, cientistas de dados e entusiastas da tecnologia.
A Python Brasil 2021, evento promovido pela comunidade brasileira de Python, traz nesta edi√ß√£o uma agenda imperd√≠vel para quem quer mergulhar no universo de uma das linguagens de programa√ß√£o mais utilizadas na atualidade.
Uma das principais novidades deste ano √© a trilha de atividades em espanhol, que vai trazer ao evento palestras de toda a Am√©rica Latina, criando um ambiente de muita diversidade onde as comunidades Python de l√≠ngua espanhola v√£o poder se conectar e trocar experi√™ncias.
Em sua 17¬™ edi√ß√£o, o evento ser√° realizado de forma online, gratuito e aberto para qualquer pessoa de 11 a 17 de outubro. √â esperado um p√∫blico de mais de 10 mil participantes de todas as partes do Brasil e do mundo.
Nos sete dias de imers√£o, os participantes poder√£o contribuir para projetos de software livre, participar de treinamentos e adquirir novos conhecimentos com outras pessoas da comunidade.
E que tal falar sobre aquele projeto inovador, dar dicas sobre carreira ou mostrar formas de usar a tecnologia para causar impacto social, tudo isso em um ambiente inclusivo, seguro e acolhedor?! At√© o dia 12 de agosto voc√™ poder√° submeter sua proposta para apresenta√ß√£o de palestras e tutoriais na maior confer√™ncia Python da Am√©rica Latina.
Voc√™ poder√° acompanhar a Python Brasil pelo YouTube em tempo real e tamb√©m participar de atividades e interagir com toda a comunidade pelo servidor do Discord criado especialmente para o evento.
N√£o deixe de seguir o perfil do evento no Instagram ou Twitter para ficar por dentro das √∫ltimas novidades!
articles.title: Participe da Python Brasil 2021, a maior confer√™ncia de Python da Am√©rica Latina

articles.title: CSS Ruled Paper

articles.author: Benjamin Delespierre
articles.description:
Uncle Bob's Clean Architecture is quite the hype right now in the architects' world. But when it comes to actual implementations, nothing notable has been proposed for Laravel.
And that's understandable: Laravel's MVC architecture and its tendency to let you cross layers all the time using Facades doesn't help designing clean, decoupled software parts.
So today, I'm going to present you a working implementation of the Clean Architecture principles inside a Laravel app, as explained in The Clean Architecture by Robert C. Martin.
The complete, working implementation of the concepts explained here is available on my GitHub repository. I recommend you have a look at the actual code while reading this article.
For once, let's get our hands clean üëç
 
The architecture must support the use cases.‚Ä¶
articles.title: How to implement Clean Architecture with Laravel

articles.author: Nazeeh Vahora
articles.description:
In the previous blog, we discussed deploying our Smart Contract to the Rinkeby Test Network and interacting with it from our front end. 
I decided to write this article on tests as a bonus. You should write these tests before writing the Smart Contract and integrating with the front end.
One way of testing our Contract is interacting with it manually and testing every scenario. In this, one needs to consider every scenario and test the Contract in that case. Remembering every edge case could be tedious. Also forgetting a single edge case could break our Contract. 
This is not a preferred way of testing. Instead, we should write tests for our Smart Contracts. Writing tests will check our Smart Contract in every possible scenario and ensures our Contract behaves expectedly. If any of the tes‚Ä¶
articles.title: Testing Solidity Smart Contracts

articles.author: Sean Kerwin
articles.description:
Hey everyone.
So, I'm an avid Apple Mac user, and I've used macOS as my primary dev environment for over 10 years.
This has been mostly down to that my employer provided me with a top end Macbook Pro, so I have done everything within the apple ecosystem.
My current employer, the boss was pretty cool, I could set my mac's up how I wanted, have personal emails/icloud on it, use it for personal stuff and side-work (out of work hours ofcourse), So I've had no real reason to switch.
I have just taken a new job, and decided that I want my own machine, keep work and personal stuff separated.
Dell were doing an amazing deal on their outlet website for the XPS range of laptops, and I managed to pickup a brand-new XPS 13 9305 with 16GB Ram, and i7 Quad Core, with 512GB M2 SSD, for ¬£800.
The only pro‚Ä¶
articles.title: Pop!_OS -  The first week!

articles.author: Brad Westfall
articles.description:
A hopefully well received and educational response to "why react sucks" - https://dev.to/jfbrennan/really-why-react-5958
JSX templates
JSX is not a "templating language", it's actually considered to be the antithesis of one. Templating languages suffer from becoming a DSL (domain specific language) whereby the "language" must recreate things like conditional logic and iterations with some proprietary "template language syntax" that will never be able to do as many things as it's host language.
JSX was added as a way to avoid using React's own createElement API.
Not at all, React.createElement is the underlying API for React to which JSX was created specifically to compile to. It's not like JSX was created long after React to "avoid something". Instead, the main idea is that any programmati‚Ä¶
articles.title: Why React? Because it's pretty cool actually. Misunderstood at times, but cool üëç

articles.author: Erin Schaffer
articles.description:
React is one of the most popular JavaScript front-end frameworks on the market today, and its popularity continues to grow. It‚Äôs estimated that over 8,000 companies use this JavaScript framework, including big names like Facebook, Instagram, Airbnb, and more. Many companies are looking for talented React developers. 
Cracking your React Native interview is essential to landing one of these roles. To help you prepare, we‚Äôve gathered the top 50 React Native interview questions. This guide includes questions and answers. Let‚Äôs get started!
We‚Äôll cover:
25 React Native interview questions with answers
25 more interview questions to explore
Next steps





React Native is a JavaScript framework that was developed by Facebook to meet the growing needs of mobile app development. It‚Äôs open-source ‚Ä¶
articles.title: Top 50 React Native interview questions (with answers)

articles.author: Guilherme Tadeu
articles.description:
Introduction


In this article, we'll see an explication of the most used HTTP methods such as GET, POST, PUT, PATCH, and DELETE, making an analogy with some spells from the Harry Potter universe.
Accio
Aguamenti
Vera Verto
Reparo
Reducto
Conclusion
"The Accio spell is used to summon long-distance items into the witcher's hands. To use it, one must point the wand at the object and say Accio + Name of the chosen object".

In HTTP, the Accio is equivalent to the GET method. We use it to get a representation of something. For example, to get the data of a book in the Hogwarts Library, we can make the following call in the system:
REQUEST
METHOD: GET
URL: localhost:8080/books/42

RESPONSE
{
    "id": 42,
    "name": "Quidditch Through the Ages",
    "author": "Kennilworthy Whisp"
}

A power we‚Ä¶
articles.title: Harry Potter: Understanding the HTTP Methods

articles.author: Erin Schaffer
articles.description:
Distributed systems are collections of computers that work together to form a single computer for end-users. They allow us to scale at exponential rates, and they can handle billions of requests and upgrades without downtime. Apache Kafka has become one of the most widely used distributed systems on the market today.
According to the official Kafka site, Apache Kafka is an ‚Äúopen-source distributed event streaming platform used by thousands of companies for high-performance data pipelines, streaming analytics, data integration, and mission-critical applications.‚Äù Kafka is used by most Fortune 100 companies, including big tech names like LinkedIn, Netflix, and Microsoft. 
In this Apache Kafka tutorial, we‚Äôll discuss the uses, key features, and architectural components of the distributed stre‚Ä¶
articles.title: Beginner Kafka tutorial: Get started with distributed systems
